answer_html: \(b=\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ -5 \\ 5\end{pmatrix}.\) Note that there are several choices that could be made and this method is just a quick and effective way for finding a suitable vector.
answer_latex:
$b=\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ -5 \\ 5\end{pmatrix}.$ Note that there are several choices that could be made and this method
is just a quick and effective way for finding a suitable vector.
hints_html:
Since \(\displaystyle M\) has rank 2, the columns in \(\displaystyle M\) must be linear dependent. Which column in \(\displaystyle M\) is redundant, which two columns are linearly independent?

\(\displaystyle Mx = b\) is only solvable if \(\displaystyle b\) is a linear combination of the columns of \(\displaystyle M\). How do you find a vector, which is not a linear combination of the two linear independent columns?
hints_latex:
Since $\displaystyle M$ has rank 2, the columns in $\displaystyle M$
must be linear dependent. Which column in $\displaystyle M$ is
redundant, which two columns are linearly independent?

$\displaystyle Mx = b$ is only solvable if $\displaystyle b$ is a linear
combination of the columns of $\displaystyle M$. How do you find a
vector, which is not a linear combination of the two linear independent
columns?
hints_raw:
Since <math>\displaystyle M</math> has rank 2, the columns in <math>\displaystyle M</math> must be linear dependent. Which column in <math>\displaystyle M</math> is redundant, which two columns are linearly independent?
<math>\displaystyle Mx = b</math> is only solvable if <math>\displaystyle b </math> is a linear combination of the columns of <math> \displaystyle M</math>.  How do you find a vector, which is not a linear combination of the two linear independent columns?
question: A 05
sols_html:
As calculated in A04, we take \(\displaystyle q=1, p=0\),

\[\begin{aligned} M = \begin{pmatrix}1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 5 \\ 1 & 7 & 8 \end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle M\) has rank 2, the columns in \(\displaystyle M\) must be linear dependent. We see that the second column is 7 times the first column. Hence, the second column is redundant.

The first and the third column of \(\displaystyle M\) are linearly independent since the third one has a 5 as second entry, where the first one has a 0. Therefore, there is no possible scalar such that columns 1 and 3 are multiples.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle Mx = b\end{aligned}\]

is only solvable, if \(\displaystyle b\) is a linear combination of the columns of \(\displaystyle M\).

We want to find a vector, which is not a linear combination of the two linear independent columns. Once possible choice is to find a vector which orthogonal (and hence linear independent) to the first and third column by performing the cross product,

\[\begin{aligned} b = \begin{pmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{pmatrix} \times\begin{pmatrix}3\\5\\8\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ -5 \\ 5\end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Note that there are several choices that could be made and this method is just a quick and effective way for finding a suitable vector.

and 3 are multiples.

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle Mx = b
\end{align*} is only solvable, if $\displaystyle b$ is a

We want to find a vector, which is not a linear combination of the two

\begin{align*}
b = \begin{pmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{pmatrix} \times\begin{pmatrix}3\\5\\8\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ -5 \\ 5\end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}

Note that there are several choices that could be made and this method
is just a quick and effective way for finding a suitable vector.

statement_html:
Consider

\[\begin{aligned} M = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Choose p and q such that M have rank 2. Give an example of a vector b for which the linear system \(Mx = b\) has no solution.
statement_raw:
Consider 

:<math> 
M = \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

Choose ''p'' and ''q'' such that ''M'' have rank 2. Give an example of a vector ''b'' for which the linear system <math> Mx = b </math> has no solution.
